rev.comment: /* Week 5 (November 7 â November 13) */ mv to talk-- this needs WAY more context. ie they withdrew a resolution as being redunant , they did NOT vote to start being violent
rev.diff:
Line 384: Line 384:
}} Oakland General Assembly had previously passed a statement of solidarity with the OccupyCal protest at the University of California, Berkeley. In the evening of November 9, law enforcement from Oakland Police, Alameda County Sheriff, and UC Police attempted to evict the members of OccupyCal from their encampment on the campus. Several students and at least one professor were arrested. In line with the earlier general assembly vote, members of Occupy Oakland joined in the Berkeley protest. After police removed the tents from the UC Berkeley encampment, protestors held a general assembly. It voted 569-31 in favor of an educational General Strike to be held state-wide on November 15, 2011.
}} Oakland General Assembly had previously passed a statement of solidarity with the OccupyCal protest at the University of California, Berkeley. In the evening of November 9, law enforcement from Oakland Police, Alameda County Sheriff, and UC Police attempted to evict the members of OccupyCal from their encampment on the campus. Several students and at least one professor were arrested. In line with the earlier general assembly vote, members of Occupy Oakland joined in the Berkeley protest. After police removed the tents from the UC Berkeley encampment, protestors held a general assembly. It voted 569-31 in favor of an educational General Strike to be held state-wide on November 15, 2011.
â
On November 9, protestors voted to withdraw their resolution to remain peaceful.<ref>[http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8427150 Protesters withdraw resolution to remain peaceful], ABC News, November 10, 2011</ref>
 
On November 10, the one month anniversary of the Occupy Oakland demonstration, a man was fatally shot about 25 yards away from the plaza's tent encampment.<ref name=NY10>{{cite web|last=Walter|first=Shoshana|title=Occupy Oakland and News Media Coexist Uneasily|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/13/us/occupy-oakland-and-news-media-coexist-uneasily.html|publisher=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=13 November 2011}}</ref> Occupy Oakland medics responded to the victim until the police and paramedics arrived. There are mixed reports about whether the people involved in the shooting were connected to Occupy Oakland. <ref name=NY10/> <ref name=NPR10>{{cite web|last=Kaste|first=Martin|title=Occupy Oakland Movement Tries To Regroup After Shooting|url=http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2011/11/11/142255723/occupy-oakland-movement-tries-to-regroup-after-shooting|publisher=NPR|accessdate=13 November 2011}}</ref> Randy Davis, a cameraman for KGO-TV was filming the Occupy Oakland medics rendering [[first aid]] treatment to the victim when some protesters formed a ring around the victim shouting, âNo cameras!â and âNo media!â Davis was hit in the head and pushed towards a ledge overlooking a BART station stairwell before other protesters intervened.<ref name=NY10/> In response to the shooting, demonstrators observed a moment of silence, prayer, and held a candlelight vigil for the victim, led by one of the camp chaplains.<ref>{{cite news|title=Shots fired near 'Occupy Oakland,' one dead|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8427634|accessdate=November 10, 2011|newspaper=KGO-TV|date=November 13, 2011}}</ref>
On November 10, the one month anniversary of the Occupy Oakland demonstration, a man was fatally shot about 25 yards away from the plaza's tent encampment.<ref name=NY10>{{cite web|last=Walter|first=Shoshana|title=Occupy Oakland and News Media Coexist Uneasily|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/13/us/occupy-oakland-and-news-media-coexist-uneasily.html|publisher=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=13 November 2011}}</ref> Occupy Oakland medics responded to the victim until the police and paramedics arrived. There are mixed reports about whether the people involved in the shooting were connected to Occupy Oakland. <ref name=NY10/> <ref name=NPR10>{{cite web|last=Kaste|first=Martin|title=Occupy Oakland Movement Tries To Regroup After Shooting|url=http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2011/11/11/142255723/occupy-oakland-movement-tries-to-regroup-after-shooting|publisher=NPR|accessdate=13 November 2011}}</ref> Randy Davis, a cameraman for KGO-TV was filming the Occupy Oakland medics rendering [[first aid]] treatment to the victim when some protesters formed a ring around the victim shouting, âNo cameras!â and âNo media!â Davis was hit in the head and pushed towards a ledge overlooking a BART station stairwell before other protesters intervened.<ref name=NY10/> In response to the shooting, demonstrators observed a moment of silence, prayer, and held a candlelight vigil for the victim, led by one of the camp chaplains.<ref>{{cite news|title=Shots fired near 'Occupy Oakland,' one dead|url=http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8427634|accessdate=November 10, 2011|newspaper=KGO-TV|date=November 13, 2011}}</ref>
